thread.title: 'No rescue': NBN boss defends Government loan
thread.title_full: 'No rescue': NBN boss defends Government loan

author: Peter Ryan
title: 'No rescue': NBN boss defends Government loan
text:
By senior business correspondent Peter Ryan Updated February 03, 2017 09:02:33 Map: Australia 
NBN Co chief executive Bill Morrow says the $49 billion project is rolling out on time and on budget, despite having to secure a special loan from the Federal Government late last year. 
The $19.5 billion top-up, in addition to the government's $29.5 billion capped contribution, was negotiated on commercial terms, despite original expectations that the private sector would be tapped to cover any shortfall in the NBN's budget. 
However, Bill Morrow has rejected suggestions that the Government's intervention to cover the additional costs raises questions about the private sector's confidence that the NBN will be a viable investment when it is complete in 2020. 
Mr Morrow told the ABC's AM program he is confident the money could have been raised from the private sector, but appeared relaxed that the Government instead provided the top-up loan. 
"We did not actually tap into the banks to start the process but the government stepped in and said they would loan it to us rather than have us go to that market," Mr Morrow said. 
"We're pleased with that because it made our life much simpler to secure those funds." 
Mr Morrow denies the $19.5 billion government loan was a "rescue" because private markets were unenthusiastic about investing in the NBN. 
"No it wasn't a rescue at all. It was clearly just prudency and managing taxpayers money than leaving it to us to go to the external markets," Mr Morrow said. Concerns raised over NBN's value 
Mr Morrow said concerns about the final sale price of the NBN were understandable given the size and scope of the project amid reports that its value might have to be significantly written-down to attract buyers after 2020. 
Last year, consultancy KMPG estimated the NBN value might need to be written-down by as much as $25 billion to attract private interest. 
"It is the biggest [project] that the country has seen. There is a lot of money involved so it's natural to be sceptical and to be concerned," Mr Morrow said. 
"There's a lot of people that will speculate about what the value is and what will happen if it ever does come to selling. I think we should worry about that when the time comes." 
The Federal Government expects a future privatisation of the NBN and that the $19.5 billion loan will be refinanced on external markets in 2020-21. 
In a statement last year, Finance Minister Mathias Cormann said the NBN had obtained strong credit ratings, "which show that the NBN's business case is strong." 
Mr Morrow's defence of the NBN rollout coincides with the release of a report which says Australia will be the world's most connected continent after the rollout is complete in 2020. 
The report by the University of Western Sydney predicts "gen NBN" will have life changing opportunities, with flexible working arrangement and access to world leading education and healthcare services.
